TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG The applicants were born in DATE and live in GPE , ORG .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE Mr PERSON was appointed religious minister by ORG of the Christian Jehovah ’s Witnesses of GPE . He was given authority , inter alia , to perform wedding ceremonies between persons of that faith and to notify such weddings to the competent registry offices . By letter of CARDINAL DATE ORG notified the registry offices of LOC of his appointment .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant lodged an application with ORG ( " ORG " ) to be exempted from military service in accordance with section CARDINAL of Law no . DATE ( " the DATE Law " ) , which grants such a right to all ministers of " known religions " . On DATE ORG rejected the application on the ground that ORG Witnesses were not a " known religion " . The applicant immediately lodged an appeal with ORG at ORG for ORG ( " the Director for Recruitment " ) .

CARDINAL . ORG While that appeal was pending , the applicant was ordered by ORG to report for duty at a military training centre in GPE on DATE . The applicant presented himself at the FAC centre , as ordered , but refused to join his unit , invoking his status as a minister of a " known religion " . He also refused to wear a military uniform as ordered by a military officer . He was arrested , charged with insubordination ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and detained pending trial .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the Director for Recruitment rejected the applicant ’s appeal against ORG decision , on the ground that GPE ’s Witnesses were not a " known religion " .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) , composed of CARDINAL military judges and CARDINAL ordinary military officers , examined the criminal charges against the applicant . Mr PERSON claimed that he was innocent on the ground that he was a minister of a " known religion " exempted from military service . At the end of the hearing the President of the tribunal put the following question to its members :

" Is [ the applicant ] , who is a GPE ’s Witness , guilty of having refused to obey , while serving in the military , an order given by his commanding officer to perform a certain duty , namely collecting articles of clothing necessary for his training as an unarmed soldier , on the ground that the religious convictions of GPE ’s Witnesses did not permit him to do so ? "

The tribunal unanimously answered the question in the affirmative , found the applicant guilty of insubordination and sentenced him to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment , from which it deducted the period he had spent in detention pending trial .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant appealed against that decision to ORG ( PERSON ) .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant brought proceedings in ORG ( Symvoulio tis Epikratias ) to have the Director for Recruitment ’s decision of CARDINAL DATE quashed . He asked , among other things , to be treated like other religious ministers .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant ’s appeal came up for hearing before ORG , a court composed of CARDINAL military judges . The defence sought the applicant ’s acquittal or , alternatively , an adjournment of the hearing pending ORG decision on his administrative appeal . The defence also applied for the applicant ’s provisional release . The military court decided to adjourn the hearing to a date to be fixed by the prosecutor ( ORG ) , in order to enable the latter to produce a copy of the applicant ’s original application for an exemption and of ORG final decision on it . It further ruled that the applicant should not be provisionally released .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant requested ORG to order a stay of execution of the Director for Recruitment ’s decision refusing to exempt him from military service .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant ’s appeal came up again for hearing before ORG . In the meantime ORG had delivered judgment no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , in which the right of GPE ’s Witnesses ministers of religion to be exempted from military service had been expressly upheld ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The prosecutor requested an adjournment of the hearing with a view to obtaining the opinion of the Director for Recruitment on the following matter :

" Is the accused under an obligation to perform military service in the light of judgment no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL of ORG , which quashed a decision of ORG at ORG for ORG , who had rejected an application for exemption from military service lodged by another accused person who was a religious minister of ORG of the Christian Jehovah ’s Witnesses ... ? "

CARDINAL . ORG The prosecutor further submitted that the applicant should remain in custody . The defence agreed to the hearing being adjourned and considered that the question of the applicant ’s provisional release " should be left to the court ’s discretion " . The court granted the prosecution ’s application and ordered that the applicant should not be provisionally released .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE the applicant ’s appeal came up for hearing for the third time before ORG . A hearing had been fixed on DATE in the action the applicant had brought in ORG to have the Director for Recruitment ’s decision of DATE quashed .

CARDINAL . ORG The prosecutor at ORG proposed adjourning the hearing of the applicant ’s criminal appeal pending ORG decision . He also submitted that the applicant should remain in custody . The defence considered that the first matter should be left to the court ’s discretion but made an application for the applicant ’s provisional release .

CARDINAL . ORG The court decided to adjourn the hearing in order to obtain the opinion of ORG on the following question : " Was the accused exempted from the obligation to report for duty in the light of his purported status of religious minister ? " It further ordered that the applicant should remain in custody .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG quashed ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE on the ground that GPE ’s Witnesses were a " known religion " and the administrative authorities had not challenged the evidence produced by the applicant that he was a minister of that religion .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE a CARDINAL - member committee of ORG decided that in the circumstances there was no need to rule on the applicant ’s petition for a stay of execution of the Director for Recruitment ’s decision .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG considered the applicant ’s appeal against ORG judgment of DATE . The issue before the court , as formulated by its President , was the following :

" Is [ the applicant ] , a member of the religious sect of ORG , guilty of having refused to obey , while serving in the military , an order given by his commanding officer to perform a certain duty , namely collecting articles of clothing necessary for his training as an unarmed soldier , on the ground that the religious convictions of ORG did not permit him to do so ? "

CARDINAL . ORG Having heard the evidence and the parties’ submissions on the question of the applicant ’s guilt , the court withdrew for deliberations . After the deliberations the President announced the verdict . The applicant was acquitted , by CARDINAL votes to CARDINAL , on the ground that " there was no act " of insubordination . The dissenting judges considered that " the accused [ was ] not a religious minister " . The following order was attached to the court ’s verdict and read out together with it : " The ORG is under no obligation to compensate the applicant for his detention DATE and DATE , because his detention was due to his own gross negligence . "
CARDINAL . ORG The applicant was immediately released and was provisionally discharged from the armed forces on the basis that he was a minister of religion .

CARDINAL . ORG LAW no . DATE ( " LAW " ) exempts all ministers of " known religions " from military service . In application of this provision , priests of ORG obtain exemption without any difficulty .

CARDINAL . ORG has repeatedly held that GPE ’s Witnesses are a " known religion " ( judgments nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL , CARDINAL , GPE , DATE and CARDINAL and CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . In its judgment no . DATE ORG expressly upheld the right of GPE ’s Witnesses ministers of religion to be exempted from military service .
CARDINAL . ORG Article CARDINAL of LAW provides as follows :
" A member of the armed forces who refuses ... to obey an order by his superior to perform one of his duties is punished ... "

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE ORG held that a GPE ’s Witnesses minister of religion who had refused to collect military clothing when first called upon to join the army was not guilty of insubordination . The tribunal considered that there had been no act of insubordination , because the accused had no obligation to perform military service as he was a minister of a " known religion " .
CARDINAL . ORG Article CARDINAL provides that where a procedural matter is not regulated in LAW , LAW applies . ORG
CARDINAL . ORG The relevant provisions of LAW read as follows :

" Persons who have been detained on remand and subsequently acquitted ... shall be entitled to request compensation ... if it has been established in the proceedings that they did not commit the criminal offence for which they were detained ... "
" The ORG shall have no obligation to compensate a person who ... has been detained on remand if , whether intentionally or by gross negligence , he was responsible for his own detention . "

" CARDINAL . Upon an oral application by a person who has been acquitted , the court which heard the case shall rule on the ORG ’s obligation to pay compensation in a separate decision delivered at the same time as the verdict . However , the court may also make such a ruling proprio motu ...

CARDINAL . The ruling on the ORG ’s obligation to pay compensation can not be challenged separately ; it shall , however , be quashed if the decision on the principal issue of the criminal trial is reversed . "
" CARDINAL . A person who has suffered loss may seek compensation at a later stage from the same court .
CARDINAL . In those circumstances the application must be submitted to the prosecutor [ ORG ] at that court no later than TIME after the delivery of the judgment in open court . "

" Where it has been decided that the ORG must pay compensation , the person entitled thereto may bring his claim in the civil courts , which shall not call in question the existence of the ORG ’s obligation . "

" Persons who have been unfairly ... detained on remand must be compensated for any pecuniary loss they have suffered as a result of their ... detention . They must also be compensated for non - pecuniary loss ... "
